summary: 01/04/2000: The offices of a Russian-language newspaper, Novoe Vremya (New Times), in Yerevan, Armenia, were burnt down after receiving threats related to a previous article published in the newspaper on the assassination of the Armenian prime minister on October 27, 1999. The perpetrators of this incident were unknown.
target1: The offices of the Novoe Vremya (New Times) newspaper
motive: Possibly related to an article published in the newspaper on December 31, 1999, concerning the assassination of Armenian Prime Minister Vazgen Sarkisyan on October 27, 1999.
propcomment: Two editorial offices were destroyed
scite1: “Armenia: Newspaper Office Hit by Arson Attack,” ITAR-TASS, January 4, 2000.

summary: 01/25/2000: Unidentified persons opened fire on an Abkhaz militia post in Saberio, Gali District, killing two militiamen.
target1: An Abkhaz militia post in Saberio
motive: Unknown
scite1: “Georgia: Two Abkhaz Militiamen Killed in Gali District,” Kavkasia-Press (Internet Version), January 25, 2000.

summary: 02/16/2000: Tajik Deputy Minister Shamsullo Dzhabirov was killed by a car bomb. Makhamadsaid Ubaidullayev, the mayor of Dushanbe, Tajikistan's capital city, was injured by the blast as well. target1: Shamsullo Dzabirov, Tajikistan's Deputy Security Minister
target2: Makhmadsaid Ubaidullayev, the Mayor of Dushanbe
motive: To destabilize the country before parlimentary election.
scite1: Gridneva, Galina and Zhukov, Valery, "Tajik president condemns Dushanbe mayor car bomb blast," ITAR-TASS News Agency, February 16, 2000.
scite2: "Two Tajiks on trial for bomb attack which killed vice minister," Agence France Presse, March 26, 2001.

location: The centre of Stepanakert, in Nagorno-Karabakh Republic
summary: 3/22/2000: Arkady Gukasyan, the unofficial president of the Nagorno-Karabakh enclave, was shot and wounded as he was driving home in Stepanakert, in Nagorno-Karabakh Republic, Azerbaijan.  His driver and bodyguard were also injured in the attack.  The former Nagorno-Karabakh Defense Minister Samvel Babayan and his brother, Stepanakert Mayor Karo Babayan, were arrested in connection to the attack.  Government authorities stated that the attack was designed to undermine democratic reform.
target1: Arkady Gukasyan, the unofficial president of the Nagorno-Karabakh enclave
target2: The driver and bodyguard of the unofficial president
motive: Specific motive is unknown, but government authorities state that the incident was designed to undermine democratic reform

scite2: "Attempt on the life of Nagorny Karabakh president," Prime News, March 22, 2000.

summary: 04/24/2000: Unidentified armed Afghans broke into a residence in the Khatlon Oblast of Tajikistan and opened fire, killing one person and injuring another. A third person was also kidnapped. No group claimed credit for this incident and there was no information on the fate of the hostage.
motive: Unknown
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1996-2001 : A Chronology, Imprint Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 2002.

location: Tajikistan, a former Soviet republic
summary: 5/20/2000: Saifullo Rakhimov, the chairman of state-run radio and television, was shot and killed near his home in Tajikistan.  Six gunmen dressed in camouflage blocked his car and then opened fire.  Rakhimov's driver was critically wounded in the attack.  No group has claimed responsibility and authorities believe the attack was a "contracted terrorist act".

target2: The driver of Saifullo Rakhimov, the chairman of state-run radio and television

summary: 05/24/2000: The car of Otar Turnanba, a staff member of the administration of Abkhazia's Ochamchira district in Georgia, came under attack by suspected Georgian radicals in Shesheleti, Abkhazia, Georgia. Three people were injured in the incident.
target1: Otar Turnanba, a Ochamchir District Administration Staff Member
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: A grenade launcher was used in the incident.
propcomment: The car was damaged in the attack.
scite1: "Abkhaz Administration Member Attacked by Grenade Fire,” Interfax, May 25, 2000.

corp1: Xingjian Uygur Autonomous District of China Delegation
target1: A Member of an Official Delegation from the Xingjian Uygur Autonomous District of China
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: Reports of the incidents described automatic firearms being used in the attacks.
propcomment: A Mazda was damaged in the incident.
addnotes: In addition to the two Chinese delegates who were killed and injured, respectively, their Kyrgyz driver was also injured.
scite1: "Chinese Delegation Member Killed in Bishkek,” Interfax, May 26, 2000.
scite2: "Kyrgyz Gunmen Fire on Chinese Delegation,” The San Diego Union-Tribune, May 27, 2000.
scite3: "Gunmen Kill One, Wound Two From Chinese Delegation in Kyrgyzstan,” Associated Press Worldstream, May 26, 2000.

location: The incident took place near the village of Lata.
summary: 06/01/2000: A gang of unknown individuals kidnapped United Nations observers in the Kodor Gorge, near the village of Lata, Abkhazia, Georgia. The UN observers were released them four days later, on 06/05/2000, without demand of ransom. No casualties resulted from the incident.
target1: Kai Laursen and Thomas Rosenqvist, United Nations Military Observers
target2: John Woodword, a Member of Hullo Trust
motive: Unknown
addnotes: It is not certain why the gang kidnapped the observers. In the past, United Nations missionaries were kidnapped for ransom or political motives.

scite2: "Five missing in Abkhazia, including two UN observers", Agence France Presse, June 02, 2000.
scite3: "All Kodori gorge hostages freed - presidential spokesman", Prime-News, June 06, 2000.

summary: 07/16/2000: A bomb targeting a European Union vehicle exploded in Dushanbe, Tajikistan, killing one person and injuring four others. The vehicle had markings indicating that it was property of the European Community Humanitarian Aid department (ECHO). The perpetrators of this incident were not known.
motive: Unknown
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1996-2001 : A Chronology, Imprint Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 2002.

summary: 08/12/2000: Islamic Movement of Uzbekistan (IMU) rebels took four U.S. mountain climbers and a Kyrgyzstan soldier hostage in the Kara-Su Valley in Kyrgyzstan. The solider was killed and the other four hostages escaped on August 18, 2000.
motive: Unknown
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1996-2001 : A Chronology, Imprint Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 2002.

summary: 08/12/2000: Islamic Movement of Uzbekistan (IMU) rebels kidnapped six German, three Russian, one Ukrainian and two Uzbek mountaineers in Kara-Su Valley, Kyrgyzstan. The victims were eventually released, although the specific date was not known.
motive: Unknown
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1996-2001 : A Chronology, Imprint Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 2002.

location: On the Kodori Highway in the center of Sukhumi, Abkhazia
summary: 8/15/2000: Zurab Achba, an advisor for the United Nations Human Rights Sukhumi office and a leader of the Abkhaz People's Forum, was shot and killed in the center of Sukhumi, Abkhazia, Georgia.  Achba was driving home when unidentified assailants opened fire on his car.  No group has claimed responsibility for the incident and the motive is unknown.  Achba was a former deputy of the Abkhaz Supreme Soviet.
target1: Zurab Achba, an ex-deputy of the Abkhaz Supreme Soviet, an advisor for the UN Human Rights office, and a leader of Abkhaz People's Forum
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: Machine guns
scite1: "UN special representative is shocked by the murder of Zurab Achba," Prime News, August 16, 2000.

location: In the home of the military prosecutor in Yerevan
summary: 8/30/2000: A bomb exploded in basement of the home of Gagik Dzhangirian, Armenia's military prosecutor, in Yerevan, Armenia.  No one was hurt in the explosion but the house suffered minor damage.  Dzhangirian had led an investigation of the killing of the Prime Minister and other government officials by gunmen claiming that the government was corrupt.  The investigation had just finished and been handed over to the court to begin trial.  An unknown group claimed that Dzhangirian had botched the investigation and threatened to seek revenge on Dzhangirian.  However, no group claimed responsibility for the bombing of Dzhangirian's home.
target1: Gagik Dzhangirian, an Armenian military prosecutor
motive: Specific motive is unknown, but the victim had just finished leading an investigation of the killing of several key government officials, including the Prime Minister
propcomment: An explosion in the basement of a private home which knocked out the cellar lock
scite1: "Explosion rips through Armenian prosecutor's home, no one hurt," Associated Press, August 30, 2000.
scite2: "The explosion in the house of military prosecutor of Armenia," ARKA Political Information, August 30, 2000.
scite3: "Investigation will clarify reason of explosion in Armenia's military prosecutor's house," SNARK News Agency, August 31, 2000.

summary: 09/24/2000: Two police officers were shot dead with a Kalashnikov assault rifle in Almaty, Kazakhstan. The Uighur Liberation Organization is suspected.
motive: Unknown
scite1: “Kazakh police suspect Uighur "separatists" of murdering two policemen,” BBC Monitoring Central Asia Unit, September 26, 2000.

summary: 09/27/2000: One Kyrgyz soldier was wounded when a group of eight men tried to push their way deeper into Kyrgyz territory along the Kurbak mountain pass border region. The assailants suffered minor injuries in the attack.
motive: Unknown
scite1: “One Kyrgyz Soldier Wounded in Clash With Terrorists,” Moscow ITAR-TASS, September 27, 2000.
scite2: “Kyrgyz troops win another clash with militants - Kazakh agency,” Almaty Interfax-Kazakhstan, September 27, 2000.

motive: Unknown
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1996-2001 : A Chronology, Imprint Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 2002.

summary: 10/11/2000: The Chief of Personal Guards and the driver of Tajik First Vice-premier, Khodzhikbar Turadzhonzoda, were kidnapped by unknown gunmen. The two men were kidnapped in the area of the Shokhmansur market place in the center of Dushanbe, Tajikistan.
target2: The driver of the Tajik First Vice-premier, Khodzhikbar Turadzhonzoda
motive: Unknown
scite1: "Chief guard and driver of Tajik vice-premier kidnapped," Nezavisimaya Gazeta, October 12, 2000.
scite2: "Abduction of Tajik Vice Premier's Staff May Be Another Attempt To Intimidate Him," ITAR-TASS, October 12, 2000.

summary: 10/20/2000: Unidentified people heavily wounded the former Georgian minister of fuel and energy, Davit Zubitashvili, as he passed the front door of his house last night in Tbilisi, Georgia. The Ministry of Internal Affairs believed that an attempt was made to abduct the former minister but after he put up resistance, he was shot point blank.
corp1: Former Georgian Minister of Fuel and Energy
motive: Unknown
addnotes: The Prosecutor-General's Office had long been investigating corruption in the fuel and energy sphere, including the period when Zubitashvili was minister. It was reported that the attack on Zubitashvili was possibly part of a feud within the energy mafia.
scite1: “Former Georgian energy minister wounded in abduction attempt,” Kavkasia-Press, October 21, 2000.

location: On the Tbilisi highway outside of Tbilisi
summary: 11/30/2000: Antonio Trevino and Francisco Rodriguez, two Spanish businessmen working on a Georgian-Spanish joint venture, were abducted on the Tbilisi highway outside of Tbilisi, Georgia.  They were in the company of the Tbilisi police chief when they were stopped by four armed men.  The assailants physically assaulted the police chief and threw him from the car, then kidnapped the two businessmen and their car.  The car was found abandoned near Naduknari village.   On December 8, 2001, the two men were released unharmed near the Chechnya border.  No group has been identified in relation to the abduction and it is unknown if a ransom was paid.
target1: Antonio Trevino and Francisco Rodriguez, two Spanish businessmen working on a Georgian-Spanish joint venture
motive: Unknown
addnotes: It is unclear whether the captives were voluntarily released or were rescued
scite1: "Update 1 - Two Spanish businessmen kidnapped in Georgia," Reuters, November 30, 2000.
scite2: Tengiz Pachkoria, "Georgia keeps up efforts for Spanish businessmen release," ITAR-TASS News Agency, December 2, 2000.
scite3: "Kidnapped Spanish businessmen released in Georgia," Reuters, December 8, 2001.

location: An area of the Kodor Gorge under Abkhazian control
summary: 12/10/2000: Two United Nations military observers, Lieutenant Colonel Zbigniew Blechacz from Poland and Captain Eustathios Kokkinitis from Greece, were abducted while patrolling an area of the Kodor Gorge, Abkhazia province, Georgia.  The captives were released in good health on December 13, 2000.  No ransom was paid for their release and the motive behind the abduction is uncertain.  No group claimed responsibility for the incident.
target1: Lieutenant Colonel Zbigniew Blechacz from Poland and Captain Eustathios Kokkinitis from Greece
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: No mention of weapons was made
addnotes: Sources state that the hostage-takers negotiated the release of the captives, but there is no mention of the conditions of release, other than that they did not include ransom.  In addition, the hostage-takers remained anonymous.
scite1: "U.N. workers kidnapped in Georgia's breakaway Abkhazia," Associated Press, December 10, 2000.
scite2: Tengiz Pachkoria," Kidnappers of UN officers still unidentified," ITAR-TASS News Agency, December 12, 2000.
scite3: "UN confirms release of hostages in Georgia," Agence France-Presse, December 13, 2000.

location: A baggage-locker area in a railway terminal in Kokshetau
summary: 2/18/2001: A bomb exploded in a baggage locker area in a railway terminal in Kokshetau, Akmola, Kazakhstan.  A police officer that was inspecting the area was wounded in the explosion.  No group has claimed responsibility for the attack and the motive is unknown.
target2: A police officer inspecting the baggage area
motive: Unknown
scite1: "Policeman injured in Kazakh rail station blast," Interfax News Agency, February 18, 2001.

summary: 03/01/2001: Three people opened fire on the car of Kofarnihon’s administration chief, Ismaildzhon Gulov, seriously wounding his bodyguard. The attack took place in Kofarnihon, Tajikistan, and no group claimed responsibility
motive: Unknown
scite1: "Tajik Local Administration Official Survives Attempt on His Life,” Interfax, March 01, 2001.

location: The first floor of the Sadbarg shopping center in Dushanbe
summary: 04/05/2001: Two people were killed and at least 10 were wounded when an bomb containing approximately 400 grams of TNT explosive detonated in the Sadbarg shopping center in Dushanbe, Tajikistan around 4pm.  The bomb's detonation ignited a canister of natural gas in the mall, causing a serious fire and damage to the mall when all the windows were blown out.  Sources note that many of the individuals in the mall at the time were Afghans, selling various items in stores.  No group claimed responsibility for the attack.
target1: Vendors and shoppers in the Sadbarg shopping center
motive: Although the specific motive was unknown, sources detail the ongoing violence in the area due to ongoing political upheaval and the transportation of drugs and weapons into Tajikistan from Afghanistan.
weapdetail: Sources describe the bomb as containing 400 grams of TNT.  No detail was provided as to the packaging or detonation details of the bomb, nor about where the bomb was placed in the mall beyond that it detonated on the first floor.  The bomb's explosion set off a canister of natural gas in the mall, causing a serious fire.
propcomment: Sources note that all of the windows in the mall were blown out in the explosion.
scite1: "Bomb blast kills one, injures nine in Tajik capital," Agence France-Presse, April 5, 2001.
scite2: "Two killed, more wounded in Tajik explosion," Associated Press, April 5, 2001.
scite3: Galina Gridneva and Valery Zhukov, "Two killed, 10 injured in Dushanbe supermarket blast," ITAR-TASS, April 5, 2001.

location: A Dushanbe suburban street
summary: 04/11/2001: Three armed gunmen ambushed the Deputy Interior Minister's car with AK-47s as it traveled down a suburban street in Dushanbe, Tajikistan, around 8am.  The Deputy Minister was killed, as were two bodyguards and the driver.  Although no group claimed responsibility, sources conflicted as to whether this was a terrorist or criminal incident.  Four people were later arrested due to their possible group affiliation and suspected connections to the assassination of the Minister.
motive: Although the specific motive was unknown, sources suggested that this assassination could have been due to the Deputy Minister's political stance on organized crime.
weapdetail: AK-47s were used in the assassination.  It was unclear if the AK-47s used were automatic or semi-automatic.
propcomment: It was unclear how much damage was done to the vehicle.
addnotes: One of the sources notes that this case was classified as a terrorist incident by the courts and criminal proceedings were pending.
scite1: Lida Isamova, "Senior Interior Ministry official in Tajikistan shot dead," Associated Press, April 11, 2001.
scite2: Galina Gridneva and Valery Zhukov, "Killing of Tajik Dpty Interior min qualified as terrorism," ITAR-Tass, April 11, 2001.
scite3: "Four suspects detained in slaying of Tajik police official," Associated Press, April 12, 2001.

location: The AgroAction office in the region of Tavil-Dara, to the east of Dushanbe by 100 miles
summary: 6/15/2001: Fifteen people associated with AgoAction, a German agricultural humanitarian organization, were kidnapped by gunmen in the Tavil Dara region of Tajikistan.  One of the workers was American, one was German, and the rest were from Tajikistan.  Four people, including three women, were immediately released, while the remaining eleven were released two days later.  All of the hostages were unharmed.  The gunmen used to be rebels and were currently working for the Ministry of Emergency Situations.  The gunmen demanded the release of four individuals who had been arrested for an assassination that took place several months earlier.
target1: Fifteen AgroAction employees, including thirteen people from Tajikistan, one from America, and one from Germany
motive: The hostage takers wanted four of their comrades, arrested for their connections to an assassination the occurred several months earlier, released.
weapdetail: The hostages were kidnapped at gunpoint.
scite1: Akbar Borisov, "Eleven members of German aid group held in Tajikistan," Agence France-Presse, June 16, 2001.
scite2: "Gunmen seize hostages in Tajikistan," Associated Press, June 16, 2001.
scite3: "All hostages abducted in Tajikistan freed," Associated Press, June 17, 2001.

location: A residence in the village of Panik and the region of Shirak
summary: 06/25/2001: An assassination attempt on Petros Makeyan, the Democratic Fatherland political party leader, failed after a gunman shot at Makeyan with a revolver at his home in Panik, Shirak region, Armenia, around 2:00am.  Makeyan was not wounded in the attack, although it was thought that the shooter was a professional who planned out the attack in advance.  Makeyan had received death threats prior to the attempt on his life.
motive: Although the specific motive was unknown, Makeyan had received death threats before the attempt due to his political views and accusations he had made against the government in power.
weapdetail: One source describes the weapon as a TT revolver.
scite1: "Political motives behind assassination attempt on Armenian party leader," Noyan Tapan News Agency, June 27, 2001.
scite2: "Armenia-party-leader-assassination attempt on life of head of 'Democratic Fatherland' party Petros…," SNARK News Agency, June 26, 2001.

summary: 07/17/2001: Karim Yuldashev, foreign affairs advisor to the Tajik president, was gunned down outside his home by three men using silenced pistols. He was shot in the head and chest and died shortly thereafter. No one claimed responsibility for the assassination, but officials suspected Islamic militants were behind the attack.
motive: Unknown
weapdetail: The handguns were equipped with silencers.
scite1: "Tajik presidential advisor gunned down in broad daylight in capital by three assailants," Associated Press, July 17, 2001.
scite2: Abdurakhimov Rakhimov, "Unknown," Scottish Media Newspapers, Ltd., September 10, 2001.
scite3: "Three assassins responsible for gunning down Tajikistani official in Dushanbe," Interfax, July 17, 2001.

location: A road in a rural area outside of Gudava, in the Gali region of Abkhazia
summary: 07/22/2001: Four people, including two soldiers and two civilians, were killed when militants ambushed the truck they were traveling in near Gudava, Gali region, Abkhazia.  No group claimed responsibility for the incident.
target1: Two citizen traveling on the truck
motive: Although the specific motive was unknown, sources discussed other incidents of violence in the area, thought to be conducted by Georgian militants.
weapdetail: Two of the sources say the victims were ambushed and shot.  One source says that the truck they were traveling in was shelled, but this was not confirmed.
addnotes: Some authorities thought that the victims were caught in a shootout between rival gangs in the area.
scite1: "Four locals killed, Abkhazia blames Georgian guerrillas," Agence France-Presse, July 24, 2001.
scite2: Anzhela Kochuberia, "Four Abkhazians killed in terrorist act in Ghali region," ITAR-Tass, July 23, 2001.
scite3: "Four killed in Abkhaz attack," Interfax, July 23, 2001.

location: A residence in Tbilisi
summary: 07/26/2001: Unidentified individuals shot and killed Giorgi Sanaia, a journalist for the Rustavi-2 television station, inside his home in Tbilisi, Georgia.  No group claimed responsibility.  Although some claimed the attack was politically motivated, the President of Georgia claimed he did not think this was the case.
corp1: Journalist with the television program Rustavi-2
motive: The specific motive for this incident was unknown.  Some suggested that the attack was politically motivated, but the President of Georgia claimed that this was not the case.
weapdetail: No weapon detail was provided.
addnotes: Police were investigating the incident.
scite1: "Georgian TV journalist was shot dead - interior minister," Tbilisi Georgian TV, July 26, 2001.
scite2: "Georgian president confident truth will be established in TV killing," Tbilisi Georgian TV, July 27, 2001.

location: This incident occurred near the settlement of Chauvay in the vicinity of Kizilkiya, Kyrgyzstan.
summary: 08/01/2001: Ten gunmen attacked a TV station near the town of Kizilkiya, Kyrgyzstan. Security guards responded to the assault and fended off the attackers.
target1: TV transmitter and station in Kizilkiya, Kyrgyzstan
motive: The purpose of the TV station's seizure was to broadcast a report on the establishment of an Islamic state or government on CIS territory. propcomment: The barbed wired fence surrounding the TV station was damaged.
scite1: “State agency confirms attack on TV relay station,” Kabar News Agency, August 1, 2001.
scite2: “Gunmen's Failed Attempt to Seize Radio Station Delays Pres Akayev,” Kommersant, August 2, 2001.

summary: 08/12/2001: A group of about 70 Jehovah’s Witnesses were meeting in a private apartment when they were attacked by 15 assailants with sticks and metal rods in Rustavi, Georgia. The attackers set fire to religious literature and destroyed furniture and electrical equipment. Seven people were wounded in the incident.
target1: Gathering of Jehovah's Witnesses in Rustavi, Georgia
motive: Unknown
propcomment: The attackers set fire to religious literature and destroyed furniture and electrical equipment
scite1: “Another attack on Jehovah's Witnesses reported,” Prime-News, August 12, 2001.

summary: 08/17/2001: A statue of Sheikh Shamil, leader of a 19th-century rebellion against Russian forces, was bombed by an unknown group in Zaqatala, Azerbaijan.
target1: Statue of Sheikh Shamil in Zaqatala, Azerbaijan
motive: Unknown
propcomment: The pedestal was shattered and the bust cracked from the explosion. The windows of a nearby house and cars were also blown out.

scite2: “Police arrest monument bombing suspects," ANS Television, August 17, 2001.
scite3: “Caucasus guerrilla leader's monument blown up in Azerbaijan," ANS Television, August 17, 2001.

summary: 08/19/2001: An attack was launched against the police station in Zaqatala, about 350 kilometers north of Baku, Azerbaijan. Five policemen were wounded in the attack by alleged Avar nationalists.
motive: The perpetrators were trying to free comrades arrested at the beginning of August 2001.
propcomment: The police station sustained minor damage.
scite1: “Itar-Tass Russia and CIS news digest of August 19,” TASS, August 19, 2001.
scite2: “Attacks in N.Azerbaijan Attributed to Avar Separatists,” Kommersant, August 22, 2001.

summary: 08/20/2001: An attack was launched by an armed group of 30-40 ethnic Abkhaz, Armenians and Russians against residents of the Kodori Gorge in Georgia. target1: Civilians and Property in the Kodori Gorge, Georgia
motive: The incident was cited by and official as an act of provocation aimed at dragging Georgia into fresh hostilities with Abkhaz separatists.
propcomment: The attackers seized cattle and horses in the incident.

summary: 08/30/2001: A group of unidentified assailants attacked the hotel hosting Deputy Interior Minister Zahid Dunyamaliyev and First Deputy Prosecutor-General Ramiz Rzayev in Zaqatala, Azerbaijan. No injuries occurred.
motive: Unknown
scite1: “Senior Azeri northern district officials attacked,” ANS-ChM Television, August 30, 2001.

location: A residence in Tajikistan
summary: 09/08/2001: An unidentified gunmen shot Abdurajim Rajimov, the cultural minister of Tajikistan, at least five times outside of his home in Dushambe, Tajikistan around 6:00am.  Although no group claimed responsibility for the attack, it was thought that Rajimov was killed due to his central involvement in the planning of the upcoming independence day celebrations.
corp1: Cultural Minister for government of Tajikistan
motive: Although the specific motive for this assassination was unknown, it was thought that Rajimov was killed due to his central involvement in the planning of the upcoming independence day celebrations.  Also, sources note that government officials in the area had been targeted and killed recently.
weapdetail: Rajimov was shot from a short distance between five and seven times as he left his home.  One source says he was shot five times while the other says seven times.
scite1: "Tajik cultural minister killed on way to work in capital," Associated Press, September 8, 2001.
scite2: "Tajik minister of culture killed by gunman," EFE News Service, September 8, 2001.

location: A residence in Yerevan
summary: 09/11/2001: Andranik Markarian, the Prime Minister's aide and a businessman, was killed by a grenade left at his front door around 9:15am in Yerevan, Armenia.  Although no group claimed responsibility for the attack, sources thought it might be related to his business dealings.
corp1: Aide to the Prime Minister of Armenia
motive: Although the specific motive was unknown, sources speculated that the attack could have been related to Markarian's business dealings, as he was involved in importing oil.
weapdetail: The grenade was thought to have been connected to his front door so that when he opened the door to leave in the morning, it would explode.
propcomment: Sources mention flying shrapnel from the explosion, but no details on any property damage were provided.
addnotes: One of the sources says that Markarian's son was wounded in the explosion, while the other says that both his wife and son were not harmed.
scite1: "Armenia killing," Associated Press, September 11, 2001.
scite2: "Booby trap grenade kills senior aide to Armenian Prime Minister," EFE News Service, September 11, 2001.

location: This incident occurred on the ninth kilometer of the Zaqatala-Balakan road in Zaqatala District.
summary: 09/28/2001: An unknown group attacked the traffic police post number 718 on the ninth kilometer of the Zaqatala-Balakan road in Zaqatala District, Azerbaijan. They used grenades and assault rifles, wounding one person and damaging six cars. One of the perpetrators was killed in the attack as well. No group claimed responsibility for the attack.
target1: Police post 718 in Azerbaijan on the Zaqatala-Balakan road in Zaqatala District.
motive: Unknown
addnotes: The dead body of Anvar Osmanov, a resident of Katex village, an assault rifle and one large-calibre fire arm owned by the criminals was found at the scene.
